laws.summary: Pennsylvania restricts non-compete agreements for healthcare practitioners through the Fair Contracting for Health Care Practitioners Act. For healthcare workers (physicians, osteopaths, CRNAs, CRNPs, physician assistants), non-competes longer than 1 year entered after Jan 1, 2025 are void and unenforceable. Even 1-year non-competes become void if employer terminates the practitioner (even for cause). Non-competes tied to practice sales remain enforceable. For non-healthcare workers, Pennsylvania still allows reasonable non-competes under common law with no statutory restrictions.
laws.statute_citation: Act No. 74 of 2024 (H.B. 1633) - Fair Contracting for Health Care Practitioners Act
requirements: Healthcare practitioners: Non-competes longer than 1 year are void after Jan 1, 2025
Healthcare practitioners: 1-year non-competes only enforceable if practitioner voluntarily resigns
Healthcare practitioners: Non-competes void if employer terminates (even for cause)
Healthcare practitioners covered: physicians, osteopaths, certified registered nurse anesthetists, certified registered nurse practitioners, physician assistants
Exception: Non-competes connected to sale of ownership interest or practice assets remain enforceable
Employers may recover reasonable relocation, training, patient acquisition costs within 3 years if practitioner voluntarily leaves
Patient notification required within 90 days: must notify patients practitioner has left, explain record transfer process, offer assignment to new practitioner
Applies to practitioners with ongoing patient relationships (2+ years, seen within past year)
Non-healthcare workers: No statutory restrictions, common law reasonableness applies
Pre-Jan 1, 2025 agreements remain unaffected by new law
laws.notes: Pennsylvania was previously unrestricted for non-competes. New law only applies to healthcare practitioners. FTC non-compete ban blocked in court, so state law governs. Broad definition may affect patient non-solicitation agreements.

laws.summary: Philadelphia (not statewide) prohibits employers from asking about or relying on applicant salary history when setting compensation. Enforcement began September 1, 2020. Statewide, Pennsylvania has proposed but not yet enacted salary history ban legislation (H.B. 630).
laws.statute_citation: Philadelphia Wage Equity Ordinance (Philadelphia Code § 9-1131); Proposed H.B. 630 (not yet law)
requirements: PHILADELPHIA ONLY: Employers cannot ask about salary history
PHILADELPHIA ONLY: Cannot rely on salary history to set compensation
PHILADELPHIA ONLY: Applies to all positions in Philadelphia
PHILADELPHIA ONLY: Exceptions for internal transfers/promotions (can use current employer salary data)
PHILADELPHIA ONLY: Voluntary disclosure by applicant is permitted
PHILADELPHIA ONLY: Can use market salary data and surveys
PHILADELPHIA ONLY: Enforced by Philadelphia Commission on Human Relations
STATEWIDE: H.B. 630 proposes similar ban statewide but NOT YET LAW
Proposed statewide law would prohibit 'gag orders' on employee pay discussions
At state level, only notification requirements exist (must provide wage info at hire)
laws.notes: Only Philadelphia has enacted salary history ban. Statewide legislation pending. Penalties for violations include fines and potential lawsuits. Does not prevent asking about salary expectations.

laws.summary: Pennsylvania has PROPOSED but not enacted pay transparency law (H.B. 560). If passed, employers with 15+ employees would need to provide pay ranges when offering positions, promotions, or transfers, and notify current employees annually. As of Jan 2026, this is NOT YET LAW. Pennsylvania only requires wage notification at time of hire.
laws.statute_citation: Proposed H.B. 560 (not yet law); 43 P.S. § 260.3 (Wage Payment and Collection Law - notification only)
requirements: PROPOSED (NOT LAW): H.B. 560 would apply to employers with 15+ employees
PROPOSED (NOT LAW): Must provide pay range when offering new role, promotion, or transfer
PROPOSED (NOT LAW): Annual written notification to employees of their pay range
PROPOSED (NOT LAW): Transparency for jobs requiring similar skill, effort, responsibility
PROPOSED (NOT LAW): Would take effect 60 days after passage
PROPOSED (NOT LAW): Does NOT require salary ranges in job postings
CURRENT LAW: Must notify employees of rate of pay at time of hire
CURRENT LAW: Must notify of time/place of payment
CURRENT LAW: Can post information conspicuously or provide individual notice
CURRENT LAW: Must notify before changes to pay rate or payment details
laws.notes: Pennsylvania does NOT currently have pay transparency law requiring salary ranges in postings. H.B. 560 introduced Feb 2025 but status uncertain. Only basic wage notification required at hire under existing law.

laws.summary: Pennsylvania has state-level protections under CHRIA and local 'ban the box' laws in Philadelphia and Pittsburgh. State law prohibits considering arrests without conviction, requires job-relatedness assessment, and bars discrimination based on criminal history. Philadelphia has most restrictive ban-the-box law requiring employers wait until conditional offer to inquire about criminal history.
laws.statute_citation: 18 Pa.C.S. § 9125 (CHRIA - Criminal History Record Information Act); Philadelphia Code Chapter 9-3500 (FCRSSO); Pittsburgh Code § 161.16A
requirements: STATEWIDE: Cannot consider arrests without conviction
STATEWIDE: Cannot consider juvenile adjudications
STATEWIDE: Cannot consider summary offenses
STATEWIDE: Convictions must be job-related and affect suitability
STATEWIDE: Must consider: nature of offense, time elapsed, job duties, rehabilitation
STATEWIDE: Must provide written explanation if rejected based on record
PHILADELPHIA: Cannot ask about criminal history on initial application
PHILADELPHIA: Can only inquire after conditional offer of employment
PHILADELPHIA: Cannot consider convictions older than 7 years (4 years for misdemeanors after Jan 6, 2026)
PHILADELPHIA: Cannot consider summary offenses at all
PHILADELPHIA: Must conduct individualized assessment
PHILADELPHIA: Must provide copy of background report and 10 business days to respond before final decision
PHILADELPHIA: Must notify of specific convictions considered
PHILADELPHIA: Amendments effective Jan 6, 2026 strengthen protections
PITTSBURGH: City contractors cannot ask about convictions until after applicant deemed qualified
PUBLIC EMPLOYERS: Statewide ban-the-box for state government jobs (2017)
Exceptions: Positions legally required to exclude certain convictions (childcare, financial services)
laws.effective_date: CHRIA: ongoing; Philadelphia: 2012 (amended 2016, 2025); Pittsburgh: enacted; State public sector: 2017
laws.notes: Philadelphia has strongest protections. CHRIA applies statewide but doesn't prohibit asking - just limits use. Recent Philadelphia amendments (Jan 2026) reduce misdemeanor lookback to 4 years, add enhanced notification requirements.

laws.summary: Pennsylvania has NO statewide paid sick leave or paid leave mandate for private employers. Pittsburgh enacted local paid sick leave ordinance in 2020 requiring up to 40 hours for employers with 15+ employees. Philadelphia proposed but has not enacted paid sick leave. Most PA private employers have no paid leave requirements.
laws.statute_citation: Pittsburgh Code § 626.01 et seq. (Paid Sick Days Act); No statewide statute
requirements: STATEWIDE: No paid sick leave or paid leave requirement for private employers
PITTSBURGH ONLY: Employers with 15+ employees must provide paid sick leave
PITTSBURGH ONLY: Accrue 1 hour per 35 hours worked, up to 40 hours per year
PITTSBURGH ONLY: Can use for own illness, family care, domestic violence situations
PITTSBURGH ONLY: Carries over year to year
PITTSBURGH ONLY: Effective since 2020
PITTSBURGH ONLY: Employers with fewer than 15 employees exempt
PHILADELPHIA: No paid sick leave ordinance (proposed but not enacted)
Federal FMLA applies to employers with 50+ employees (unpaid leave)
Workers' compensation covers work-related injuries
Unemployment compensation available for eligible workers
laws.notes: Pennsylvania has very limited paid leave requirements. Only Pittsburgh has local ordinance. Most private employers not required to provide paid sick leave. Philadelphia's paid sick leave ordinance has been proposed multiple times but never passed.

laws.summary: Pennsylvania generally enforces arbitration agreements under common law and federal law. No specific state statute restricts employment arbitration agreements for private employers. Courts apply Federal Arbitration Act (FAA) and favor arbitration. However, agreements must be clear, mutual, and not unconscionable.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Arbitration Act (9 U.S.C. §§ 1-16); Pennsylvania common law
requirements: Arbitration agreements generally enforceable under FAA
Must be in writing and signed by both parties
Must have mutual agreement to arbitrate
Agreement must provide for neutral arbitrator
Cannot be unconscionable or one-sided
Must clearly identify what claims are subject to arbitration
Courts apply federal policy favoring arbitration
Employee must receive adequate consideration
Employer can waive arbitration right by engaging in litigation
Pre-dispute arbitration agreements are enforceable
Class action waivers generally enforceable in employment arbitration
NLRA protections: cannot prohibit concerted activity discussions
Must comply with due process requirements
laws.effective_date: Ongoing under federal and common law
laws.notes: Pennsylvania has no specific state restrictions on employment arbitration. FAA governs. Courts generally enforce arbitration agreements if procedurally and substantively fair. Some challenges on unconscionability grounds possible.

laws.summary: Pennsylvania follows at-will employment doctrine. Either party can terminate employment at any time for any lawful reason or no reason. However, numerous exceptions protect against wrongful termination including discrimination, retaliation, public policy violations, and breach of implied contract.
laws.statute_citation: Common law doctrine; 43 P.S. § 260.1 et seq. (Wage Payment); 43 P.S. § 951 et seq. (PHRA - anti-discrimination)
requirements: Default: Employment terminable at will by either party
No notice required unless contract/policy provides otherwise
Discharged employees must receive final pay on termination date
Voluntary resignation: paid on next regular payday
EXCEPTIONS - Cannot terminate for: Race, color, religion, national origin, sex, age 40+, disability, ancestry discrimination (PHRA)
Cannot terminate for: Retaliation (workers' comp claim, jury duty, whistleblowing)
Cannot terminate for: Violation of public policy (refusing illegal acts, reporting violations)
Cannot terminate for: Breach of implied contract (handbook promises, oral assurances)
Must provide UC-1609 form (unemployment information) at separation
Written employment contracts override at-will status
Collective bargaining agreements override at-will status
Employee handbooks may create implied contracts if not properly disclaimed
laws.notes: While at-will is default, many exceptions exist. PHRA provides broad anti-discrimination protections. Public policy exception protects whistleblowers. Handbook disclaimers critical to maintain at-will status.

laws.summary: Pennsylvania has NO state statute regulating private employer drug testing. Testing is generally permitted but must be reasonable and job-related. No statewide requirement or restriction. Medical marijuana users may have some protections under disability law, but recreational users have minimal protections. Testing programs must comply with federal laws for certain industries.
laws.statute_citation: No specific Pennsylvania statute; Medical Marijuana Act (35 P.S. § 10231.2103); Federal requirements for DOT/safety-sensitive positions
requirements: STATEWIDE: No statute restricting private employer drug testing
Pre-employment testing: Generally permitted, apply consistently
Random testing: Permitted, especially for safety-sensitive positions
Reasonable suspicion testing: Permitted with documented basis
Post-accident testing: Permitted for workplace incidents
Must have written drug testing policy
Must apply testing consistently within job categories
Medical marijuana: Employers cannot discriminate against medical marijuana cardholders unless use creates safety concerns or violates federal law
Medical marijuana: Cannot terminate solely for positive test if off-duty use
Medical marijuana: May prohibit on-site use and impairment at work
Recreational marijuana: No workplace protections, employers can maintain zero-tolerance
DOT-regulated positions: Must follow federal testing requirements
Federal contractors: Must maintain drug-free workplace policies
Must maintain confidentiality of test results
laws.effective_date: Medical Marijuana Act: 2016; No general testing statute
laws.notes: Pennsylvania is employer-friendly on drug testing with no statewide restrictions. Medical marijuana creates limited protections but not absolute bar to testing. Recreational users have no protections. Safety-sensitive positions have broad testing latitude.

additional_notes.general_guidance: Pennsylvania is generally employer-friendly with limited statewide employment regulations. Most restrictions are at local level (Philadelphia, Pittsburgh). No statewide pay transparency, salary history ban, or paid leave mandates currently in effect.
